answers.content: It Is works like vanila JS app
With the help of black magic

questions.question: What are some of the advantages of Angular over other frameworks?

answers.content: Features that are provided out of the box, declarative UI, long-term Google support

questions.question: Explain Components in Angular.

answers.content: Components are the basic building blocks, which control a part of the UI for any application. A component is defined using the @Component decorator. It has three three parts: template, stylesheet and class
In Angular components are the same as in React
It is a place where we can group modules
Components are objects which get instantiated only once during the lifetime of an application

questions.question: Explain Modules in Angular

answers.content: Modules are the basic building blocks, which control a part of the UI for any application
In Angular mpdules are the same as in React
The main objective of a module is to share data, functions with different components of an Angular application
A module is a place where we can group components, directives, services, and pipes

questions.question: Explain Services in Angular

answers.content: Services are the basic building blocks, which control a part of the UI for any application
In Angular Services are the same as in React
Services are objects which get instantiated only once during the lifetime of an application
A services is a place where we can group components, directives, services, and pipes

questions.question: What are lifecycle hooks in Angular?

answers.content: Hooks in Angular are objects to change the state of a component

Every component in Angular has a lifecycle, different phases it goes through from the time of creation to the time it's destroyed. Angular provides hooks to tap into these phases and trigger changes at specific phases in a lifecycle
Hooks in Angular are special components to render a page content
It is another way to name a simple function

questions.question: Can an angular application to render on the server-side?

answers.content: No, Angular uses client-side rendering only
Angular can not use both client-side or server-side rendering
Angular by default, uses client-side rendering only
Yes, angular provides a technology called Angular Universal, which can be used to render applications on the server-side

questions.question: What are directives in Angular?

answers.content: A directive is a class in Angular that is declared with a @Directive decorator. Every directive has its own behaviour and can be imported into various components of an application

There are no directives in Angular?

questions.question: Which directive is used to specify the mixin?
What for is @use rule for?

answers.content: The @use rule allowes you to define complex operations on SassScript values that you can re-use throughout your stylesheet.
The @use rule allowes you to define styles that can be re-used throughout your stylesheet.
The @use rule loads mixins, functions, and variables from other Sass stylesheets, and combines CSS from multiple stylesheets together
The @use rule loads a Sass stylesheet and makes its mixins, functions, and variables available when your stylesheet is loaded with the @forward rule.

questions.question: What is interpolation in SASS?

answers.content: There is no Interpolation in SASS
Interpolation can be used almost anywhere in a Sass stylesheet to embed the result of a SassScript expression into a chunk of CSS
You assign a value to a name that begins with $, and then you can refer to that name instead of the value itself
Allow you to define complex operations

questions.question: What is Parent Selector?

answers.content: The parent selector, &, is a special selector invented by Sass that’s used in nested selectors to refer to the outer selector
The parent selector, %, is a special selector invented by Sass that’s used in nested selectors to refer to the outer selector
The parent selector, #, is a special selector invented by Sass that’s used in nested selectors to refer to the outer selector
The parent selector, @, is a special selector invented by Sass that’s used in nested selectors to refer to the outer selector

questions.question: What is Placeholder Selectors?

answers.content: It looks and acts a lot like a class selector, but it starts with a <@:) and it's not included in the CSS output.

It looks and acts a lot like a class selector, but it starts with a ^ and it's not included in the CSS output.
It looks and acts a lot like a class selector, but it starts with a % and it's not included in the CSS output
